comments.commentBody:
The common denominator among Trump's appointments and inner circle is the sycophantic badge of honor they all hold for following him to the depths of human decency for the sake of enhancing their own careers. Brushing aside his ignorant proclamations, misogynistic outbursts and racist rants. And now, Mitt Romney who warned in March that to chose Trump for President "the prospects for a safe and prosperous future are greatly diminished", comes in search of an appointment. Is there no level they will not stoop to?
What an unseemly spectacle!

If DT picks Romney or indeed any other rational 'never Trump' Repub, for a spot in the administration, and they accept, they're exhibiting a great degree of self-sacrifice, in order to try to keep the ship of state on an even keel. We need all sane hands on deck.
Perhaps Romney would accept the appointment for the good of our country, hoping he can inject a modicum of intelligent sanity into the administration?
At least Romney is a grownup, though.  At least there will be one flawed but not horribly awful person in their midst.

Jeff Sessions is a virulent opponent of marijuana legalization and is a member of the Reefer Madness Pot Prohibition Society

"Good people don’t smoke marijuana" said Pastor Sessions.

Pastor-Prosecutor Sessions Attorney General Sessions will start his Medieval Marijuana Inquisition by prosecuting millions of Americans in Alaska, California, Colorado, Oregon, Massachusetts, Nevada, Washington, Maine, and Massachusetts for selling and enjoying recreational marijuana...especially those that lack the proper milky white pigmentation in their skin.

In 1986, the late Senator Ted Kennedy said it was 'inconceivable … that a person of this (Session's) attitude is qualified to be a U.S. Attorney, let alone a United States federal judge.'

Kennedy later said 1986 hearings created a 'clear and convincing case to gross insensitivity to the questions of race' on the part of Sessions.

The late Senator Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio called Sessions a man of ''marginal qualifications who lacks judicial temperament.… a nominee who is hostile, hostile to civil rights organizations and their causes."

http://www.alternet.org/election-2016/jeff-sessions-alabamas-neo-confede...

As Trump said earlier this year, "there has to be some form of punishment"

Welcome to Donald Trump's vision of 21st century America.

Grand Old Punishment
Grand Old Prisons
Grand Old Patriarchy
Grand Old Prohibition

Jeff Sessions is ready to punish America good and hard.
drugs are bad!  but drug companies are good!   I'm confused.
I guess I am not good then.
If road blocks to test drivers for intoxication by legal alcohol is legal why would ones to test for illegal marijuana by illegal?

Well, they can really, considering that around 90% of the indentured servants died before the 7 years were up. And occasionally if they did survive, a few would default on the agreement, refusing to give up land and bribing the law to look the other way.

But no matter anyway, the subject of slavery is ancient history and it has no place in modern society, at least not a civilized one. Unless people accept what happened and move on, we can never have true equality. What happened was a terrible injustice, but it was done by people who have long since been dead to people who have long since been dead.

Affirmative action works on the basis that minorities are incompetent, and need the support of whites in order to succeed. It doesn't matter the "logic" used to justify it, it's a racist system spawned from the desperation of wanting NOT to appear racist.

It's far more logical to have an Affirmative Action based on income, as this gives poor kids of every race a chance, instead of just the minority ones, who could still actually be rich and benefit from the AA.
(Ultimately I agree that indentured servants are not slaves, but they are comparable.)
No.  The probably thought they won, and, come to think about it, so do I.  In fact, didn't Trump say that he never settles?  Oh yeah, he never lies, either.

You cannot normalize a narcissistic sociopath. Trump is a textbook case. He is a clear and present danger to our country and he should not serve as president. He lost the popular vote by a large amount and there was voter suppression by Republicans in key electoral college states. We are better than a Trump presidency.
How are the wealthy "exonerated," except by the agreement of the plaintiffs?  Nobody forced them to settle.

Hi Kim!
Just In case you see this...
All you have to do is copy/paste the url into the comment box, and it will show up as a 'hot link' when it appears in the published comment. Could hardly be easier.

I'm guessing *not* Toronto?

After the election, I asked my son who is now applying for a residence in Psychiatry, if he thought Trump might feel satisfied, and be a bit more thoughtful and considerate. He said, he didn't think so. Intuitively he thought that Trump would feel substantiated and even more powerful. That It's possible, the worst is yet to come.

Your son is ahead of his training in understanding that narcissists need to keep getting their "narcissistic supplies" because at heart they have an unfillable hole where self-esteem should live.
And, woe, the narcissist who DOESN'T get the adoration he thinks he is owed. It's a thing called "narcissistic rage" and it's totally out of proportion to the injury. Hold on, it's going to be a bumpy ride.
Benefit?  They only got back part of what they paid in.  Trump benefited by failing to deliver on what they were sold.  If Trump wew a normal person he would be humiliated.

All that misplaced adulation for the wisdom of the Founding Fathers, the US Constitution with its perfect balance between competing political forces, the rich heritage of an immigrant culture that made the US a nation like no other in the history of the world. What we were really looking for all the time was a not-too-bright rich guy with good ole boy values.

Partha, thanks must be said to the ignoramuses who voted for him, those who don't have a clue what a gift they're flushing down the toilet. You are seeing American Exceptionalism practiced by exceptionally stupid Americans.

i will never support asystem that would give such political power to population centers like nyc, tecm the very fopks who always are the causes of depressions and recessions in the usa. the founding fathers had it right the first time like so many things that have survived in the constitution. they were not  paid off like todays elected leaders. they did what they did in fear of losing their lives as opposed to our leaders whose biggest fear is the loss of a future lobbying job and the private country club.

Sessions claims he is not a racist. In his mind, he probably isn't a racist. As far as he is concerned, he is merely supporting a conservative agenda. What does racism have to do with it? His cause lies outside the bounds of racism.

That's how they convince themselves that their policies are not racist. He is just trying to fight crime and purify the electorate. That's all.

I've been around plenty of conservatives in my life and that is how they think. To them, their policies don't say do this or that to black people, so they are not racist. Religious freedom in no way can be homophobic. They don't hate gay people, they just don't want them around. They harbor no hatred of black people. They just want to throw people in jail for 20 years for smoking a joint. They don't hate Mexicans, they just want to make sure any that have lived here for 20+ years and have raised children here get deported.

It's all about policy, not race. The conservative agenda is concerned with protecting the homeland, fighting crime and preserving our way of life. If some want to live differently, then its OK to create prohibitions against those differences if the majority desires them. Thats not racism or homophobia. Man, that's liberty! That's how people like Sessions see the world and that's why they are so dangerous.
Here here

Jim....the Lord will provide....white spite, hate, racism, hypocrisy and the most deplorable Americans conceivable.

Let us pray....for more Christian ill will toward others...Amen.
Really, heaven forbid people actually obey laws.

Well professor Rash,

Your neighbors voted for coal, then and now. The are willing to die for it, to cut down mountain tops , pollute the streams, make the fields and forests unusable.

They did not stop the destruction of their environment, when the coal companies wanted to dig more or drill more, only a few stood up and demanded more responsible mining.The put up with unsafe working conditions, black lung disease, and all the other illnesses that come with mining it. They forewent medical plans, let the coal barons get rid of the unions, caved in to the threats of being put out of work.

so now, the work is gone, the water undrinkable, the forests and mountain tops gone, the streams polluted, a classic case of short sighted thinking. They did not encumber their minds with thinking, they left them blank, believing it would last forever.

Now it has become a dinosaur, expensive to use, dirty, and inefficient. they blame environmentalists. But California set the example when it outlawed coal burning trains in the late 1800s pr early 1900s. California was fortunate to have large oil reserves, the people and legislators understood the how damaging it was then.

Of course the coal industry promoted as much use of it as it could, now it is being replaced by cleaner power sources. Those citizens of Appalachia helped bring it on themselves, they have no one else to blame. It is they , who let the coal companies have their way, now they are paying the price.

This comment is, unfortunately, ignorant of any of the facts of the dynamics of getting "rail roaded" for generations. Similar things are said about a lot of class-oppressed people. It’s easy to just say “fix yourself”. It’s ironically what "progressives" and (I guess this is what you might call them) "atavistics" both prescribe. Like all those homeless folks in San Francisco, African Americans in Compton and Oakland, Native Americans all over the state and nation, Mexican Americans that have to listen to how you say things like San Rafael and nevertheless own the place, and on and on.  Your attitude is also weirdly violent; as reactionary as the folks who voted "wrong" and act out too. Make no mistake, you prescribe that harm come to others here. They deserve to be harmed you say. You say they are others, other than you and yours. But the people of Appalachia are various. They are people, and Americans, as well as you. Odd to have to remind both sides in this kind of mutual sneering of that central fact. The conditions in Appalachia and the exploitation of the place and people are also various, not all dystopian but too often bad, the worst of it well documented but not really understood. Certainly not by you here. This country is worth the work. The wrecking ball of balkanism is always attractive to angry people. We have a right to be pretty angry right now, but so do these people that have been misled and railroaded for so long. It’s time now for good work to be done.

There are PLENTY of other people to blame. Very wealthy people have spent immense amounts of money to destroy the unions and promote lies and undermine democracy -- ending with the debacle of a fascist shyster in the White House.
Well given your attitude why should anyone care? You take no responsibility for your choices and where by the way are solutions from the GOP? In the bank accounts of Massey coal company owners.

Gail, thanks for the observations. As always, I enjoy your take on things. To be completely honest I am done with all of it. Hillary is no saint, but you can't argue with her credentials. Democracy is messy by design and those involved at the highest level will, by necessity, make deals. These folks are not saints, they are professionals.   He won, by the rules of the electoral college. I'm tempted to say that it's not my America, but it is our reality, and I still live here, although my commitment to our republic is growing burdensome.  Retreating from globalization is a natural reaction for most of us in the middle, but it's only postponing the inevitable. The old white guys in charge will have their last stand. It may echo for some decades, but ultimately it is a loosing proposition. God bless the Republic.
Yes, may it rest in peace.
Two million more voters freely chose Clinton than chose Trump.
It's only been a week and a half. Way too early to make any judgements.

So what I get from this is that the market and its prognosticators are just as clueless as the news media.  If the market is thinking that Trump can be managed, they haven't been paying attention.  What you saw during the campaign is how he will respond as President.

It was interesting to watch Obama and Merkel at their press conference when they were talking about Trump. The expressions on their faces reminded me of the expressions I saw on TV during the economic collapse in 2008. Faces of doom.
We are doomed.
yeah, faces of doom from the folks who never lost their government paycheck but coddled to the very banks who created the misery.  lets all get out our tiny violins and play for them.
Not legally.  But of course, as President, he can appoint a head of the Treasury who will let him take any deduction he wants.
But isn't  Trump just the kind of president the electoral college is supposed to protect us from?  Let tbem do their jobs!
Not under the law.

Although it makes for grim reading Dr. Krugman is correct.

Certain facts are apparent and irrefutable: that Donald Trump is a charlatan and swindler in business, and has been for years; that he is a documented sexual predator; that he is a pathological liar; that he is devoid of empathy, to the point of mocking and taunting a disabled man on television. He is in fact a sociopath; no other conclusion fits the evidence.

We have never before elected a sociopath President, and are therefore in absolutely uncharted and terribly dangerous circumstances. The worst possible response is to act as though Donald Trump, and our national peril, are in any way normal.

As Eleanor Roosevelt put it, "It is better to light a candle than curse the darkness."  Focusing on Trump is a mistake; I expect him to be largely ineffective and possibly only haphazardly involved.  I am more concerned with the actions of Congress and the people gathered around Trump.  Vigilance is important looking forward, but so is pointing to a better way forward.
Frankly, right now cursing the darkness seems like a pretty good idea.

I have had the pleasure of eating at Noma three times in Copenhagen, and each time was a unique experience.  However, slowly it looks like Rene Redzepi is loosing the plot gallivanting all over the world with his pop-up restaurants.  I'm sure it is great fun for him and his staff but to me his uniqueness has peaked sometime back, and other and better restaurants have now taken advantage of his lack of focus.  My new favourite in Copenhagen the 3-star Geranium Restaurant is a good example.

Everything I am reading about what is going on in this country, the reactions of Republicans, and their planned actions, it is bringing on a bad case of deja vu.

This is all the bad parts of the Nixon presidency without the good parts. The protests are being treated with the same disdain as the Vietnam War protests. The day after the election my 88 year old mama said, don't worry, he'll go too far and eventually be impeached like Nixon. However, I cannot be sure that will happen. The people who voted for Trump have a high tolerance for all kinds of illegal activity by their idol. I don't think they will ever admit "this time he has gone too far." I hope I am wrong.
As long as Republicans hold the House and Senate, the chances he will be impeached, much less convicted, is nil. Today's Republicans are not like the ones we had when Nixon was about to be impeached.

And Democrats did not have a "high tolerance for all kinds of illegal activity"?  Sorry, most of the "illegal smoke" was swirling around Clinton, not Trump.  Perhaps your party should have nominated a candidate that could beat the weakest Republican in history.  And as long as your "protests" are composed of violence and the destruction of private and public property, they probably will continue to be treated with "disdain."  By the way, how many Tea Party or Trump riots have there been.  Oh yeah, zero.

This is worse than the election of Nixon. He had eight yers experience as VP and knew how the government is supposed to function.Bt yes he did surround himself with Deplorables as did Reagan and George W.

Interesting column, but one thing is missing.  I'd like to see an analysis of the vote for "others."  In many states -- especially swing states (except for Iowa) --  and nationally, the votes for "others":  mostly Johnson, Stein, McMullin, when added up up exceeds the margin by which the winner's votes exceeded the loser's.  These votes might have made a difference nationally.  Who was those people's second choice?  If there had been no third-party candidates, what would have happened?

I'll tell you what would have happened.  Clinton would have LOST by an even greater margin.  Your candidate lost, against the most unprepared and unpopular major party candidate in our nation's history.  She ran a disastrous, wholly uninspiring campaign.  So begin the process of acceptance and stop entertaining fanciful counterfactuals.  The votes cast for Stein and Johnson belong to them, and them only.

Sorry, but you can't blame this on "third party candidates". (And Nader did not ruin Gore's chances of victory, either.)

Hillary knew the score going in. She knew about Johnson and Stein. She had the best and brightest on her team -- the Ivy Leaguers. She had the quants and the analysts. She had $1.5 BILLION war chest to spend as she wished, on staff and on travel and on constant advertising.

I live in a swing state, so I got to see ALL of her advertising -- nothing positive, it was all Trump attack ads, using snippets of his most controversial statements. It backfired on her. It was supposed to create outrage, especially amongst women voters, but I think it became so negative and numbing, that it had the opposite effect. (In contrast, Trump's ads were very muted and positive with a "Morning In America" tone. And he ran only a small number, even at the end. She had to have outspent him by a factor of 12 to 1.)

The reality is the Hillary effed up. There is no way around this. She knew this was about the Electoral College. She knew she needed every Midwestern state. She's a poor campaigner. Her staff massaged her ego and fed her lies. The lefty media colluded with her campaign, in ways that are yet to come out. The voters smelled a rat, and voted accordingly.

Oh and "Debbie Wasserman Schultz". That woman is pure evil.

I voted for Jill Stein. In a swing state. Had she not run, I  would not have voted at all. So, please stop blaming third parties for the outcome of the election. This constant blaming of others for ones own failures is so ingrained in the Democratic Party that no introspection and learning will ever take place

To quote President Obama "elections have consequences". As Mr Obama told Mr. Paul Ryan - "We won". Mr. Sessions is a racist according to the NYT. How about Robert Byrd who was a card carrying Klansman? Oh I forgot, he was a democrat. Bill Clinton was a protege of J. William Fulbright - an avowed segregationist. But that was OK.

Sorry I don't buy any of this. If Hillary nominated a pro marxist anti white individual we would be told how great the choice was by the NYT.
well said.   It's about time someone spoke up without fear of reprisal.
Charles repeats a lie. Hate does that.
Please stop it! My mouthful of coffee streamed out of my nose and has ruined my newspaper.  My ribs and my face hurt so much from laughing, No more please?
